Founded by Damon Smith and Martin Marquet, who together have more than two decades of experience in film production, distribution, acquisitions, journalism, and film publicity, Goodest Media aims to support artistically free, editorially rich and substantially original feature-length and short media initiatives.
Damon Smith
damon.g.smith@gmail.com

Maineland
Director
Miao Wang
Sales Agent
Cargo Film & Releasing
  • Website: mainelandfilm.com
  • Release date: October 2017 in New York / Los Angeles
  • SXSW Jury Award for Excellence in Observational Cinema
  • IFFBoston Special Jury Prize Winner

Filmed over three years in China and the U.S., Maineland is a multi-layered coming-of-age tale that follows two affluent and cosmopolitan teenagers as they settle into a boarding school in blue-collar rural Maine. Part of the enormous wave of "parachute students" from China enrolling in U.S. private schools, bubbly, fun-loving Stella and introspective Harry come seeking a Western-style education, escape from the dreaded Chinese college entrance exam, and the promise of a Hollywood-style U.S. high school experience. As Stella and Harry's fuzzy visions of the American dream slowly gain more clarity, they ruminate on their experiences of alienation, culture clash, and personal identity, sharing new understandings and poignant discourses on home and country.

Epicentro
Director
Hubert Sauper
Executive Producers
Michael Donaldson
Impact Partners
  • In Production
  • With funding provided by Ford Foundation & JustFilms

As the very place where the New World was discovered, Cuba is both a romantic "time capsule" of American and world history ‚Äî and a warning. While the beauty and decadence of the 50s have been preserved through economic embargos and isolation, the island allows us a glimpse ‚Äì bleak or optimistic ‚Äì into the planet's future: in the event of global energy scarcity, and widespread cultural or financial crisis, large parts of the world could face a similar kind of existence. Through encounters with ordinary people, the director of Darwin's Nightmare takes us on a journey into the thoughts and dreams of Cuban society in an era of transition and change, placing his film characters at the center of a far bigger planetary narrative.

Anbessa
Director
Mo Scarpelli
  • In Development
  • Initial funding provided by Catapult Film Fund

Asalif is a 10-year-old boy who lives on the very edge of a modern world. His home is a toolshed perched on the divide between an unfinished condominium complex in Addis Ababa and the vast farmland being eclipsed by its construction. Each day, Asalif lives in uncertainty of being displaced again. As he watches a condo take shape, he is reminded in small and big ways that his country's new dream of "progress" is not for him. But Asalif wants a slice of modernity, too. To gain it requires courage, so Asalif channels the persona he most reveres: the lion. In Ethiopia, the anbessa ‚Äî "lion" in Amharic ‚Äî is the premier symbol of strength for a troubled world. Asalif the Lion can take on anything, as long as he can turn reality into stories about animals and conquests of good versus evil. Filmed over the course of two dynamic years and inspired by Asalif's wild imagination, ANBESSA is a part-verit√©, part fairytale film that reveals a pivotal time in Ethiopia's history. Through its coming-of-age tale, ANBESSA captures one boy taking on modernization on his own terms, to reveal a unique and magical perspective on the myth of "progress" that entraps us all.

Lord of
Obstacles
In collaboration with
Kirsten Johnson
  • In Development
  • Presented at 2017 CPH:FORUM

Lord of Obstacles is a haunting cinematic observation and exploration of human-elephant conflict in the remote Indian state of Assam, where the world's only known river-dwelling herd of Asian elephants ‚Äì driven out of the wilderness by overdevelopment and illegal human settlement ‚Äì wreaks havoc on local farming villages in dramatic nighttime raids along the Brahmaputra floodplain. At stake in this quasi-mythic physical and psychological battle are the lives of over 200 endangered mammals and the livelihood of poor ethnic minorities whose crops, food, and homes the wandering tribe of angry elephants target and plunder.

Sisters With
Transistors
Director
Lisa Rovner
  • In Development
  • Supported by BFI Documentary Fund
  • Presented at 2017 CPH:FORUM

Sisters with Transistors is the remarkable untold story of female pioneers in electronic music who embraced machines and their liberating technologies to utterly transform how we produce and listen to music today. Starring Clara Rockmore, Daphne Oram, Bebe Barron, Delia Derbyshire, Else Marie Pade, Pauline Oliveros, Wendy Carlos, Eliane Radigue, Suzanne Ciani, and Laurie Spiegel, the film will map a new history of electronic music through the visionary women whose radical experimentations with machines redefined the boundaries of music.

Coming to
Our Senses
The Story of Alice Water's
Edible Schoolyard Project
Director
Peter Chang
  • In Development
  • In Collaboration with Golden Gate 3D

Legendary restaurateur and sustainable food pioneer Alice Waters (founder of Berkeley's Chez Panisse and doyenne of the Slow Food Movement) leads us on an cinematic adventure to re-animate our most essential relationship to growing, cooking and eating local foods. Waters narrates the origin story of her groundbreaking Edible Schoolyards Project, a public school curriculum that provides wholesome, fresh and organic meals and gives students hands-on experience in kitchens, gardens, and lunchrooms at more than 5,400 schools in the U.S. and abroad. This film will use the immersive giant screen and IMAX format to activate all five senses‚Äîsight, sound, taste, smell and touch‚Äîtaking the viewer on a sensory, educational and inspirational odyssey from schoolyard gardens to sustainable farms across the globe. Generous, and restorative, the film will bring to life Alice Waters' successful model and vision of a "delicious revolution" that aims to empower the world's youngest generation to be the agents of real environmental change.

Maison Poil√¢ne
Director
Benjamin Marquet
  • In Development
  • In collaboration with Emmy Award winning producer H√©l√®ne Badinter

Celebrated Parisian baker Apollonia Poil√¢ne is the young and gifted proprietor of the world-famous Poil√¢ne bakery, "the Louis Vuitton of boulangers," (The New Yorker), which she inherited after a tragic helicopter crash that killed both of her parents. Stepping into her father Lionel's shoes at the tender age of 18 was only the first of many challenges for the future executive chef, who has faced numerous obstacles in her quest to maintain tradition, quality and sustainability at the Poil√¢ne house. Under her meticulous direction, Poil√¢ne continues to deliver 5,000 loafs of bread daily to international clients, using a recipe and an artisanal baking process that has not changed since 1932. Maison Po√Ælane will recount the extraordinary Poil√¢ne family saga while following Apollonia across the world as she launches a new initiative, the Ker Ceres Project, an ambitious undertaking to engage the entire world in Poil√¢ne's wealth of knowledge about cereals, ancient grains, and fermentation.

Kassav
Director
Benjamin Marquet
  • In Development
  • In collaboration with Los Productions

Nicknamed "The Rolling Stones of the French Indies," long-running Creole music act Kassav is one of the most famous bands in the world. Drawing on a musical heritage that goes back to the cotton fields and sugar cane plantations of their Afro-Caribbean ancestry, Kassav invented an original style of fast-paced, high-energy dance music called zouk that has remained wildly popular for decades, inspiring collaborations with stars such as Stevie Wonder, Ray Barreto, and Miles Davis, among others. Even today, the band routinely sell out football stadiums and arenas in Paris, Tokyo, and New York and have performed for millions of fans since 1979.

In their big-screen film debut, Kassav gives us an intimate glimpse into their lives and work as they prepare to celebrate their 40th anniversary with an original repertoire that includes over 600 songs. With exclusive access to the performers and live concert events, the filmmakers tell the story of Kassav's origins and rise to world fame, placing the founding members of the band at the center of a larger narrative about Afro-Caribbean and Afro-American history that resonates with a strong message of pride in hybridity and multicultural ethnic identity. Featuring Wyclef Jean, Youssou N'Dour, Earth Wind & Fire, Nile Rodgers and other musical legends.

Untitled Film Project
on China's Sexual Revolution
Director
Miao Wang
  • In Development

The award-winning director of Beijing Taxi and Maineland explores how China's younger generation, liberated from traditional notions of love and marriage in the wake of profound cultural transformation, are expressing their sexuality in unusual and even radical new ways.
